resource descriptions.descriptionText: PubMed is a searchable database of medical literature and lists journal articles that discuss Wallenberg syndrome. Click on the link to view a sample search on this topic.

resource descriptions.resourceName: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS)
resource descriptions.descriptionText: The National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS) collects and disseminates research information related to neurological disorders. Click on the link to view information on this topic.

The Monarch Initiative brings together data about this condition from humans and other species to help physicians and biomedical researchers. Monarch’s tools are designed to make it easier to compare the signs and symptoms (phenotypes) of different diseases and discover common features. This initiative is a collaboration between several academic institutions across the world and is funded by the National Institutes of Health. Visit the website to explore the biology of this condition.

The The Internet Stroke Center, a project supported in part by the NIH Specialized Programs of Translational Research in Acute Stroke (SPOTRIAS) Network and the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS), offers information on Wallenberg syndrome.

overviewQuestion.answerText: Wallenberg syndrome is a condition that affects the nervous system. Signs and symptoms may include swallowing difficulties, dizziness, hoarseness, nausea and vomiting, nystagmus, and problems with balance. Some people have uncontrollable hiccups, loss of pain and temperature sensation on one side of the face, and/or weakness or numbness on one side of the body. Wallenberg syndrome is often caused by a stroke in the brain stem. Treatment addresses each symptom and may include a feeding tube for swallowing problems, speech and/or swallowing therapy, and medication for pain. While some people's symptoms may improve within weeks or months, others may have long-term neurological problems.[13435]

basicQuestions.questionText: What are the signs and symptoms of Wallenberg syndrome?
basicQuestions.answerText:
Wallenberg syndrome may cause a variety of symptoms depending on the specific cause and the exact location of the damage to the brain. Symptoms may include:[13439][13435]
  • pain and temperature sensory loss on one side of the face as well as on the opposite side of the body
  • rapid involuntary movements of the eyes (nystagmus)
  • problems with balance and gait (walking) coordination
  • vomiting
  • vertigo
  • nystagmus
  • dysphagia
  • hoarseness
  • uncontrollable hiccups
  • Horner syndrome (decreased pupil size, a drooping eyelid and decreased sweating on the affected side of the face) with visual deficits

references.authors: Louis DW, Dholakia N, Raymond MJ
references.articleTitle: Wallenberg Syndrome with Associated Motor Weakness in a Two-Week-Postpartum Female

basicQuestions.answerText:
The most common underlying cause of Wallenberg syndrome is a brain stem stroke in the vertebral or posterior inferior cerebellar arteries of the brain stem.[13435][5050] However, several other disorders or conditions reportedly have been associated with Wallenberg syndrome, including:[5050][5060][5061][5062][5063]

  • mechanical trauma to the vertebral artery in the neck
  • vertebral arteritis (inflammation of the wall of the artery)
  • metastatic cancer
  • hematoma
  •  aneurysm of the vertebral artery
  • herpetic brainstem encephalitis (relating to herpes)
  • head injury
  • arteriovenous malformations (AVMs)
  • multiple sclerosis
  •  varicella infection
  • brainstem tuberculoma (a rare form of tuberculosis)

references.authors: Qiu W, Wu JS, Carroll WM, Mastaglia FL, Kermode AG
references.articleTitle: Wallenberg syndrome caused by multiple sclerosis mimicking stroke
Demyelinating disease presenting as Wallenberg's syndrome. Report of a patient

references.articleTitle: Lateral medullary syndrome following varicella infection

references.articleTitle: Lateral medullary syndrome caused by penetrating head injury
Lateral medullary syndrome due to brain stem tuberculoma

basicQuestions.questionText: How might Wallenberg syndrome be treated?
basicQuestions.answerText: Treatment for Wallenberg syndrome focuses primarily on relieving symptoms and rehabilitation. A feeding tube may be needed for severe swallowing problems. Speech and/or swallowing therapy may be helpful. Medications may be used to control pain.[13435] Treatment may also depend on the underlying cause and/or how quickly it is identified.

basicQuestions.questionText: What is the long term outlook for people with Wallenberg syndrome?
basicQuestions.answerText: The long-term outlook for someone with Wallenberg syndrome depends on the size and location of the area of the brain that is damaged. Some people have improvement of symptoms within weeks or months, while others are left with significant neurological problems for years.[13435]

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.
